data.minimum_wage: The monthly minimum wage in Colombia is COP 1,423,500.

payroll.payroll_cycle: The payroll cycle in Colombia is either bi-monthly, paid on the 15th and last day of each month, or monthly.
payroll.13th_salary: Paying a 13th-month salary is mandatory in Colombia. The employer must pay one additional monthly salary split in two payments: the first half paid within the first 15 days of June and the other half paid within the first 20 days of December. These will be pro-rated when a full year has not been worked.

working_hours.general:
By law in Colombia, the maximum number of working hours is 8 hours per day and 46 hours per week.
Worker’s non-working time must be respected and employers should not contact them after working hours.
Under Law 2101, the maximum weekly working hours will further reduce to 44 hours per week in July 2025, and then down to 42 hours per week in July 2026. This reduction will not negatively affect worker salary, benefits or the value of the daily working hour.
working_hours.overtime:
All work above the standard weekly working hours is paid as overtime and regulated by the Employment Contract/Collective Agreements. The payment of overtime is generally based on the following:
Daytime (6am to 9pm) overtime is paid at 125% of the regular pay rate, increasing to 175% of the standard pay rate for night-time (9pm-6am) overtime hours.
Sunday/extra daytime/public holiday overtime work is paid at 175% of the regular pay for holidays and night-time work and 125% for overtime work during the daytime.
Nigh Shift Surcharge – An employee who has to work between 10pm-6am must be paid 35% more than the equivalent daytime salary, even if it is their regular working hour.
Employees who hold managerial roles, director positions, jobs with significant decision-making authority and those paid salario integral are generally exempt from the standard overtime limits as these roles typically require flexibility and greater responsibility. Employees not on a salario integral must be paid separately for overtime working.

leave.annual_leave_(vacation): Paid leave in Colombia is outlined in the employment contract as a minimum of 15 days paid leave a year, following completion of 1-year service. This is in addition to any public holidays.

leave.sick_days:
For the first 2 days of sick leave, employees are entitled to be paid full salary by their employer. From day 3 to 90 of sick leave, payment is made by the Social Security system at a rate of 66.67% of the workers salary. From day 91 to 180 of sick leave, payment is made by the Social Security system at a rate of 50% of the workers salary.
The the law requires that the employer makes the sickness payments for the 180 days period, which they can then request a reimbursement from the Social Security system.
A medical authorization from the Colombian Social Security system must be obtained for the employee to be eligible for paid sick leave.
leave.maternity_leave:
Employees are entitled to 18 weeks of paid maternity leave.
The payment of maternity leave it is done based on the declaration at the moment of the start (of the leave), reported on the first day of the leave by the employer to the social security.
Employees with integral salary, are entitled to 70% of the salary, while employees under ordinary salary set up are entitled to is 100%, of their wage. therefore, the maternity pay paid during the leave is the one that fits the declaration.
The employer pays this and is then fully reimbursed by social security.
leave.paternity_leave: Employees are entitled to two weeks (14 calendar days) of paid paternity leave at 100% of their regular salary rate. The employer pays this and is then fully reimbursed by Social Security (EPS).
leave.parental_leave: There is no additional parental leave in Colombia.
leave.other_leave:
Bereavement Leave: In the event of the death of an immediate family member, an employee is entitled to up to 5 days’ leave in Colombia.
Marriage Leave: Employees are also entitled to 5 days’ leave in the event of their marriage.
Voting Leave: Employees are entitled to half a day of paid leave to vote in elections.

termination.termination_process:
The termination process is standard in Colombia and is based on labor law requirements unless an employer can provide sufficient cause for dismissal without notice (due to misconduct, etc.).
Notice of termination must be in writing and sent to the relevant governmental authorities.
The employer must make payment to leavers on their last day at work.
termination.notice_period:
For Employees under fixed employment contracts, employers must notify employees at least 30 days before the contract’s expiration if they do not intend to renew it, otherwise it will be automatically renewed for the same
period of time. For indefinite contracts, no notice period is required, though it is common to give 15 days. Though notice is not legally required during the probation period, providing a courtesy notice (e.g., 1-2 weeks)
common by both parties.
termination.severance_pay:
In Colombia, severance pay is mandatory if applicable and determined by the employee’s length of service and the rate of earnings.
If the employee earns less than 10x the minimum monthly wage, the severance payment entitlement is 30 days for the first year of employment, plus 20 days for each additional year of service.
If the employee earns more than 10x the minimum monthly wage, the severance payment entitlement is 20 days for the first year of employment, plus 15 days for each additional year of service.
Severance  is not paid when the employee resigns voluntarily. Compensation is only paid when the employer dismisses the employee without just cause.
termination.probation_period: The probation period in Colombia is optional. It is recommended to set a probation period of 1/5 of the contract duration up to 2 months. For permanent employees, it is generally two months.

visa.general_info:
Any foreigners coming to work in Colombia will need to have a job offer from a local employer before applying for a visa. There are several visa types, but the most commonly used is the M visa which is valid for five years. These visas are issued in person at the Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores’ offices in Bogota.
Every foreigner with a visa valid for more than three months needs to apply and obtain a foreigner’s identity card at a regional office. This must be obtained within 15 days of entering Colombia or 15 days after the visa was issued.
Once five years have been completed, foreign nationals can apply for an R visa; then, once an individual has held an R visa for five more years, they can become a Colombian citizen.

data.remote_work:
Work From Home
Employers are required to respond within 5 days to employees’ written working from home requests. Employees may carry out their work overseas if permission is given by their employer. Teleworkers’ employment agreements must include a description and any restrictions and responsibilities regarding equipment and software, the mode of teleworking, the required working hours, the location of teleworking, reimbursement of expenses, ergonomics and technology, among others.
It is possible for the employer and the teleworkers to expressly agree in the employment contracts or amendments on the reversibility of teleworking at any moment.
Employers are required to reimburse employees for teleworking-related expenses which are not normally incurred by employees. Employers and employees may agree a monthly allowance to compensate internet, telephone, and energy costs.
In Colombia, a home working allowance is not universally mandatory. Specific regulations apply based on salary and work arrangement:
For higher earners, there is no legal obligation for such allowances, but they can be agreed upon in employment contracts or company policies.
Employers should perform medical examinations for their remote employees when they are hired and on a periodic basis. Remote workers who are caring for minors under age 14, individuals with disabilities or adults over age 60 are allowed to organize their work schedule around their caregiver duty.
All workers have the right to disconnect and avoid any work-related contact outside their working hours and statutory or contractual leaves.
Remote Work
Remote work can be agreed upon voluntarily by the employer and employee, whereby an employee may conduct their services from any place within the country. The entire labor relationship, from its beginning to its termination, may be conducted without any face-to-face meetings at a designated workplace.
All workers have the right to disconnect and avoid any work-related contact outside their working hours and statutory or contractual leaves.
